p.s: Amir Kapoor is the protagonist of the play Disgraced, Scene 3 by Ayad Akhtar.
He is married to the white artist Emily who convinces him to assist an innocent Muslim at court.
For this reason he does not get promoted at his Jewish law firm, but instead of him Jory does, the wife of Isaac, Emily's art dealer, with whom she has slept with, as Amir finds out later this scene.
Amir is from south-Asian origin and in his 40s.
He was born into a Muslim family but he renounced his faith and to keep his religious background a secret, he even changed his name.
He is a person who, when he is enrages likes to present it verbally.
He uses a lot of swear words like ..., you walk away from me in mid-fucking sentence? (p. 71, ll. 24-25).
This shows that he does not hide his anger and wants others to see that he is angry too.
Besides, Amir also has anger issues.
After he found out that Emily and Isaac were kissing, he blames Jory although she got cheated on as well and is neighterneither guilty of the affair or is to blame for getting the job.
First you steal my job and now you try to destroy my marriage?(p. 72, ll. 18-19).
He is in kind of a rush and acts on behalf of his anger and only really realizes what he has done when he finally cooled down a bit.
Oh my god...(p. 74, l. 15).
This stresses that when Amir is angry, he can notcannot deal with it and lets it out on others, even if they are innocent.
Moreover, he hates the feeling of betrayal.
When he finds out about the cheating, Jory's promotion and Mort retiring, he gets hurt and furious, because all of this was happening behind his back.
You waited a week to tell me this?p. 71, l. 23.
This underlines that he values honesty.
Additionally, Amir is not that empathic.
Because although Amir has to deal with racism himself and knows how hurtful it can be, he still calls Jory a racist slur (cf. p. 72, l. 30).
This shows that he often does not think about othersothers' feelings, especially when he is angry.
Furthermore, he is also influenced by former experiences.
When he spits Isaac in the face (p. 72, l. 40) he is doing what his mother taught him in his childhood and by hitting Emily (p. 74, l. 5) he is acting on an interpretation of the quaranQuran.
So although he renounced his faith and wants to distant himself from the Islam, it is still a part of him and affects his actions.
All in all one could say that Amir is a round character that has to deal with anger issues and the shadows of his past.
